data.title: Tommaso Francesco (Savoia) di Savoia-Carignano (1596-1656)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

This page has been accessed 6,976 times.

Biography

Tommaso Francesco di Savoia was an Italian military commander.

First Prince of Carignano (Principe di Carignano).

Tommaso Francesco di Savoia, Principe di Carignano (English: Thomas Francis of Savoy, Prince of Carignan), was born on 21 December 1596 in Torino. Tommaso was the youngest of the five legitimate sons of Carlo Emanuele I, Duca di Savoia (Charles Emmanuel I, Sovereign Duke of Savoy), by his consort Catherine Micaela of Spain, a daughter of King Philip II of Spain and the French princess Elizabeth de Valois.

In 1625 Tommaso wed Marie de Bourbon. Tommaso di Savoia and Marie de Bourbon had seven children who survived infancy:

Princess Cristina Carlotta (Christine Charolotte) di Savoia (born and died in 1626);

Princess Luisa Cristina (Louise Christine) di Savoia (1627–1689), wed in 1654 to Ferdinand Maximilian von Baden-Baden (1625–1669);

Prince Emanuele Filiberto Amedeo di Savoia (1628–1709), 2nd Principe di Carignano, in 1684 wed Princess Angela Catherina d'Este (1656–1722), granddaughter of Cesare I d'Este, Duke of Modena;

Prince Amedeo di Savoia (1629 – died young);

Prince Giuseppe-Emanuele (1631–1656), count of Soissons;

Prince Ferdinando di Savoia (1637);

Prince Eugenio Maurizio di Savoia (1633–1673), count of Soissons and Dreux, wed Olimpia Mancini.

Tommaso Francesco di Savoia died probably of malaria on 22 January 1656 in Torino.

Theoretical Relationship to Francois Savoie

The biggest unknown factor is whether Tomas Francesco is the father at all of "Prince" Francois Savoie, and if so, through which alleged mother.

The official record for the official marriage to Marie shows no such birth evidence "in wedlock" A 1621 birth of Francois would be "out of wedlock" by 4 years early.

OR...

The other option is as reported that the alleged son of Tomas, Francois reported on his deathbed that he was Tomas' son for whatever that was worth. Who his mother was is unclear if this is true. If not Marie Bourbon, then the unknown partner in a nonmarried relationship hereto known as Mrs. Savoy is the only conclusion.

Controversy not intended here, just historical accuracy.

A lot hinges on the paternity and maternity of the alleged son "Francois Savoie" born 1621.
